name: mirounga-leonina
definition: The southern elephant seal  is one of the two species of elephant seals.
description:
The southern elephant seal is the largest extant marine mammal that is not a cetacean.

It gets its name from its massive size and the large proboscis of the adult male.

The southern elephant seal is distinguished from the northern elephant seal by its greater body mass and a shorter proboscis.

This species also exhibit the greatest sexual dimorphism of any mammal in terms of mass ratio, with males typically 5 to 6 times heavier than females.

On average female southern elephant seals weigh 400 to 900 kilograms and measure 2.6 to 3 meters long.

By contrast, bulls can range from 2,200 to 4,000 kilograms and grow to 4.2 to 5.8 meters in length.

Southern elephant seals live in sub-Antarctic and Antarctic waters that feature brutally cold conditions but are rich in the marine foods these seals enjoy.

Southern elephant seals breed on land but spend their winters in the frigid Antarctic waters near the Antarctic pack ice.

These seals forage largely on deep-sea cephalopods and other molluscs, and various fish species, including lanternfish and nothothens.

Their diet also include krill and other crustaceans, and even algae.

Weaned pups, juveniles and even adults of up to adult male size may fall prey to killer whales.

Cases where weaned pups have been attacked and killed by leopard seals and sea lions have been recorded.

Great white sharks have hunted elephant seals near Campbell Island, while bite marks from a southern sleeper shark have been found on surviving elephant seals in the Macquarie Islands.

Elephant seals are polygynous, and the dominant male is in control of mating access to a group of females.

After a gestation period of 7 to 9 months a single pup is born.

Pups are born with fur and are completely black.

Their coats are unsuited to water, but protect infants by insulating them from the cold air.

Pups are generally weaned around age of 20 to 27 days.

Elephant seals are among the seals that can stay on land for the longest periods of time, as they can stay dry for several consecutive weeks each year.

While on water, these seals spend very little time on the surface, usually a few minutes for breathing.

They dive repeatedly, each time for more than 20 minutes, to hunt their squid and fish, at depths between 400 and 1,000 meters.

Southern elephant seals are the deepest diving air-breathing non-cetaceans and have been recorded at a maximum of 2,388 meters in depth.

After their near extinction due to aggressive hunting in the 19th century, southern seal population recovered and currently is estimated at 325,000 animals.

Most of their important breeding sites are now protected by international treaty, as UNESCO World Heritage Sites, or by national legislation.

Southern elephant seals are currently classified as Least Concern on the IUCN Red List of threatened species.

related.definition: The northern elephant seal  is one of two species of elephant seal .
The South American sea lion is a sea lion found on the coasts of South America.
The Australian sea lion is a species of sea lion that is the only endemic pinniped in Australia.
The leopard seal is the second largest species of seal in the Antarctic.
The walrus  is a large flippered marine mammal with a discontinuous distribution about the North Pole in the Arctic Ocean and subarctic seas of the Northern Hemisphere.
The crabeater seal s a true seal with a circumpolar distribution around the coast of Antarctica.
